body:
Because you cannot entrust a fallible entity to define what is acceptable, let alone one so easily prone to doing so in self-interest and pursuing their own agenda.

How can you determine the truth if not all viewpoints are heard? And why must one party determine what is allowed for everyone? If they find it offensive, that means they should not engage in it themselves, not that they should seek to prohibit those who disagree from enjoying it like AHS does. Any censorship advocate should consider what would happen if the tables were turned.

body: I believe it's an inalienable right. No matter how stupid or unnecessary I find someone's comments, I will defend their right to say it, tooth and nail. The art of being able to hear someone else's opinion and remain unoffended is also the mark of a mature, enlightened person.

body: Because as soon as we start banning speech, we start banning thought. Human thought is inextricably linked with language and if certain words or ideas are banned, then those things cannot be discussed. There is a slippery slope argument that is very, very valid with things like “hate speech.” This slippery slope has led to Reddit and Twitter becoming what they are today, where Twitter hides the *sitting US President’s* tweets because they disagree with them.

body: I despise the monoculture I see in people, especially the relatively younger American generations, and increasingly, all developed countries’ younger generations. I think people should diversify in what they do instead of there being “cultural watersheds” or “blockbusters”. I think free speech is a good way to do that and expose everyone to things outside of their comfort zone, so that we don’t develop these subconscious Pavlovian reactions to words and ideas. For me, that was seeing some stuff on the internet that were initially shocking to me, but which I now see as more indicative of the extremely narrow box that we’re directed to think and react within. That lack of variety is what drives people towards looking for it in fiction (and even there, it’s superficial; all morals in it are based on a single, arbitrary, recent moral system developed by a small cabal in Hollywood, California, and sometimes, Tokyo).

body:
The free exchange of ideas is important for philosophical diversity, just as the free exchange of bodily fluids is vital for genetic diversity.

Both are sometimes gross and sometimes fun, but the world would suck without either one.

body:
Here is my simple explanation. The internet is our primary platform to express ourselves in the information age. I believe that the right to assembly should also apply online in some domain. Especially now, when every single social media site is owned by a handful of corporations, all of which exercising progressively more intense levels of censorship. Our ability to speak, and what we can say, is now determined by a very small group of extremely wealthy and authoritarian multi-national corporations. What happens when entire ideologies are forbidden under this monopoly? Where do those people go? To say this scares me is an understatement. People often rebuttal that by saying "just make your own website" but this is an illogical demand. We are talking about the common-person here. They cannot just materialize a monolithic multi-billion user social media site. Larger social media sites will also *always* be more stable, because the very censorship we languish is appealing to most consumers and advertisers alike. They *love* it. A website like Ruqqus is fallible. This has already been discussed, people *will* try to destroy this website and silence us. This website is already financially unstable because it depends on donations. We don't have the resources to deflect giant hordes of neanderthals. Most people don't know what the fuck a VPN is, or DuckDuckGo, or Torr, so those aren't answers either. The real answer is that online speech needs to be protected somehow. Because this is the future of communication. Again, the constitution stipulates a "right to assembly", but what happens when everyone communicates online? This clause starts to mean nothing. Voices cease to exist. Look at the great firewall in China. Who dictates what can and can't be seen online? Corporations. In all their greed, selfishness, political pandering, and futility. Our nation will be no different than China. Corporations will control *everything*.

This is why 

My longer explanation is kind of obnoxious and philosophical but [here it is](https://www.reddit.com/r/Libertarian/comments/grj8i2/trump_threatens_to_shut_down_social_media/fs16mdt/) anyway, from reddit when i was arguing about the trump twitter drama

Most people don't know what the fuck a VPN is, or DuckDuckGo, or Torr, so those aren't answers either. The real answer is that online speech needs to be protected somehow. Because this is the future of communication. Again, the constitution stipulates a "right to assembly", but what happens when everyone communicates online? This clause starts to mean nothing. Voices cease to exist. Look at the great firewall in China. Who dictates what can and can't be seen online? Corporations. In all their greed, selfishness, political pandering, and futility. Our nation will be no different than China. Corporations will control everything.

This is why

My longer explanation is kind of obnoxious and philosophical but here it is anyway, from reddit when i was arguing about the trump twitter drama

post.body:
A lot of you obviously give a shit about free speech, since you're here and not Reddit. 

But why?

Why is it so important to you to be able to say any stupid thing that comes into your head, no matter how rude or awful or LITERALLY VIOLENT?

What does freedom of speech mean to you?
post.body_html:
A lot of you obviously give a shit about free speech, since you're here and not Reddit.

But why?

Why is it so important to you to be able to say any stupid thing that comes into your head, no matter how rude or awful or LITERALLY VIOLENT?

What does freedom of speech mean to you?
post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body:
As an English teacher, I know enough literary history to know just how bad of an idea it is when the government had control of what speech is acceptable. For example, I own a book of poetry called Howl by Allen Ginsburg. When it was first published, the feds literally took the whole shipment and tried to charge Ginsburg and his publisher for being obscene.

I’m also in the process of joining the Orthodox Church. You ask those folks about what it was like when the government didn’t allow people to own Bibles and they became rare. Communities would literally tear them into sections that could be traded around and read piecemeal - that way if one person was caught, you only lost a small part rather than the whole book. We still have folks living who grew up like this, and it makes me thankful for the freedoms I have.

If you ever want a good fictional take on censorship, read Fahrenheit 451. Bradbury calls attention to the issue of what happens when you give into the censorship calls of one group - all the other groups demand the stuff they find offensive be removed as well. It’s ultimately the people who allow or even want censorship so they don’t feel uncomfortable, but we need to remind people why feel uncomfortable is better than the alternative.

post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body:
It represents the ability to remember and analyze history. To hold onto an idea, but still be presented with something that may change your view. Even in fiction there can be a perspective that could have significant positive impact, or change world views. "Dangerous" ideas, whatever that maybe considered to the individual, can be heard and engaged. Also it will help prevent radicalism. For example, if someone has nothing but negative experiences with black people and begins to be racist, if every person after only attacks them and shuts them down, they will find the others and create echo chambers where they will spiral into cult like zealots. If the majority of these people were exposed to a wide range of ideas from a wide range of sources, most would change and never become some kind of skin head or something. There's danger in free speech as well, with propaganda and echo chambers, fake news, whatever, but for those that are trying to better themselves or society or the world or whatever, will want a place to discuss ideas that could potentially be "wrong" because they don't know, or they want to try and change minds, or a whole host of potential reasons. Those punk kids with a know it all attitude usually get humbled by life anyways, if they were engaged with actual intellectual debate, they will also learn to learn, learn they may be wrong about a position or opinion. Some people with certain mental issues could benefit from hearing ideas that might be considered taboo in most circumstances. 

Mainly I'd say it's because open discussion actually causes progress, if we aren't afraid to discuss opinions, we will be less afraid to compromise when we can understand where "the other side" is coming from. It will help everyone to see greater perspectives outside their bubbles in the world.

body:
I don’t. “Freedom is more precious than anything,” right? *Wrong*. A man will only be pushed so far–he will only endure so much ridicule, only tolerate so much filth–before he has had enough. He will realize what ‘degeneracy’ is. He will see how it has destroyed nations, ruined families (even the very concept of family). He will see it spread disease, poverty, and hatred. He will see fools brag about how “tolerant” they while they march to the guillotine. He will bear witness to the horrors of undiluted, animalistic ‘freedom.’ There’s nothing wrong with ‘freedom’ when it is focused on the good and pure. Libertarianism can (temporarily) work in a 100% demographically pure Protestant Anglo-Saxon society. Libertarianism is suicide when you live in a progressive, multicultural hellhole.

We must restore the natural laws. No more can we let people decide for themselves, as not only does it lead to our destruction, but to theirs, too. Africans [admit](https://archive.fo/pyMCd) they were far happier and more prosperous under colonialism. So were we–that’s the truth. We all need leadership, and we need to enforce what is right. We have to return to a hierarchical world where opinions mean little; only cold hard facts will be used to determine how we will run society. We have always been obsessed with the truth. You will learn that truth is more important than freedom. The truth of the world is that we are not equal and freedom destroys us. The truth of the world is that women are happy when they are mothers and that they differ from men in many aspects. The truth of the world is that African and European societies are irreconcilably different, and that if we insist on treating them equally we will only harm ourselves and them. The truth of the world is that jews hate non-jews and are trying to destroy us, and that if we do not fight to defend our right to exist, we will lose it. The truth is that there is nothing wrong with fighting back. The truth is that there is nothing our enemy hates more than us discovering the truth, specifically that the ‘freedom’ of degenerate hedonism is truly slavery. **Truth is more important than freedom.**

post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body:
Censorship is a slippery slope. Who decides what "hate speech" is? Who decides if something's violent? Who decides if something's rude/awful? These things may sound easy to identify, but in reality they're not. Words are subjective, and there are always multiple ways to interpret statements, ways to twist them into something they're not. I don't believe anyone should have the power to decide what's okay to say and what's not. Just look at what Reddit did with their new rule. That right there is a peak example of people attempting to define what's okay, and doing an absolutely shitty job at it.

In addition, when you just let people say what they want, they at least have a chance of engaging in conversation/arguments that might eventually change their mind. Censor them, and that just pushes them to the few places that will let them speak: echo chambers in the dark corners of the internet, where their views are just reinforced. Censoring people makes them more hateful, more certain of their beliefs, and more certain that _they_ are the ones being oppressed and the rest of the world is ignorant. 

Just let people say what they want. If it offends you, maybe just take a moment to think about who's problem that is. Should you really be wasting your time getting emotional over pixels on a screen? You have the freedom to stop reading, to leave that sub, block that person—whatever. You also have the freedom to criticize that person, and maybe try to talk reason into them, have a discussion. 

Freedom of speech is everyone's right. Even if I disagree with what you say, I defend your right to say it.

I don't believe anyone should have the power to decide what's okay to say and what's not. Just look at what Reddit did with their new rule. That right there is a peak example of people attempting to define what's okay, and doing an absolutely shitty job at it.

In addition, when you just let people say what they want, they at least have a chance of engaging in conversation/arguments that might eventually change their mind. Censoring people makes them more hateful, more certain of their beliefs, and more certain that they are the ones being oppressed and the rest of the world is ignorant.

Just let people say what they want. If it offends you, maybe just take a moment to think about who's problem that is. Should you really be wasting your time getting emotional over pixels on a screen? You have the freedom to stop reading, to leave that sub, block that person—whatever. You also have the freedom to criticize that person, and maybe try to talk reason into them, have a discussion.

Freedom of speech is everyone's right. Even if I disagree with what you say, I defend your right to say it.

A lot of you obviously give a shit about free speech, since you're here and not Reddit.

body:
It helps people to stop murdering each other in some degree. 

Also it allows questions on otherwise taboo subjects, like history, science and religion.

body: I think that considering the situation if the tables were turned is really the biggest issue here.  It's a complete failure to realize that ideas and thoughts are ever-changing.  Just because one side is in "control" right now doesn't mean it's always going to be that way.  History has shown that the ones in power change over time, and I feel like a lot of people don't realize that what they push for now could very well be used against them in the future when they're not in control anymore.  I support free speech because I don't want the ideological landscape to turn into a flip-flopping machine that "cancels" whoever isn't part of the dominant ideology.

parent.body:
Because you cannot entrust a fallible entity to define what is acceptable, let alone one so easily prone to doing so in self-interest and pursuing their own agenda.

How can you determine the truth if not all viewpoints are heard? And why must one party determine what is allowed for everyone? If they find it offensive, that means they should not engage in it themselves, not that they should seek to prohibit those who disagree from enjoying it like AHS does. Any censorship advocate should consider what would happen if the tables were turned.

post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body:
Banning speech is essentially banning the freedom to express one's thoughts and hear other people's ideas. Hearing other ideas (including wrog ones) is vital to finding truth since you can identify where your beliefs are weak and either need to change or the argumentation for it needs to be reworked. 

Without freedom of speech everything turns into a circlejerk echo chamber where differing opinions never interact with each other and nobody changes their mind. There's already an issue with people seeking out information that confirms their preexisting beliefs on the internet, so not allowing people to express differing opinions means there's even less of a probability of encountering counterpoints that you haven't considered yet.

body: Myriad reasons, many of which have already been offered in this thread. One missing is the way lacking free speech safeguards tend to shift the focus of modern political deliberation towards "what can be said?" from "what can be done?". It reduces our capacity to emphatize (you need to hear the opposition to do so), compromise, and work on important common problems as political actors increasingly attempt to exploit the opportunity to shut down opposition. It opens the door for extremely destructive spiral of uncompromising authoritarianism based on vague accusations and toxic identity politics. When one party utilizes the lazy power play "these people are inherently bad -> whatever they say is bad -> bad should be banned" it can be difficult for others not to follow suit.

body:
>Woah

Better than “oof yikes,” I guess.

>viewpoints

Not relevant. Truth is objective.

>What experiences

Why is it always about subjectivity and anecdotes with jews? Can you explain that about your collective psychology? Experiences are totally irrelevant to truth. I don’t have to have any experience with pollution to know that environmentalism is a necessity for the health of a nation. I don’t have to have any experience with resource extraction to know that asteroid mining is essential for the future of human civilization. I don’t have to have personally met a jew to have had my entire nation ruined thereby. As spiritual as judaism *claims* to be, you folks sure don’t believe in the objectivity of reality itself. That’s where you run into such trouble, because everyone else on the planet knows truth is objective, so anyone operating out of accordance with that is eventually liable to be on the wrong side of a backhand.

>childfree jewish

Wonderful.

>working toward my MD

Less wonderful, since you’re commanded by your holy doctrines to become doctors to take Christians’ lives. Ah, well.

>I guess I'm just wondering what your source of information is.

The Talmud, the Shulchan Aruch, the Zohar, the documents which founded the United Nations, historic interviews and books written by the jews of the late 19th and 20th centuries, public documentation of jewish behavior dating back to pre-Christian times, every law written by Western nations since 1945...

You know, basically the sum total of the whole body of work on this subject.

Careful you don’t say anything true that happens to hurt people’s feelings. You’ll be out of a job faster than you can say, “Oy vey, but neurochemistry differs between the five races of humanity!”

post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body: If we start restricting what people say, no matter how well intended, we will eventually end up in a place where you can't say anything the majority disagrees or you'll get killed. Look at all the authoritarian regimes that have existed. What is one of the first things they try to control? Speech. Why? Speech is the communication of ideas. If you control what can be said, you can control what people think, and if you can control what people think, you can do whatever you want.

post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body:
For a number of reasons.

1. **Sunlight is a good disinfectant** - If you ban ideas or certain words, they become taboo. It doesn't solve the problem of those thoughts existing, it just pushes them underground. If people *see* idiotic racist comments, they know it exists and most rational people will make fun of the hateful stuff anyway.
2. **I have the right to say what I want** - Especially being from the US, freedom of speech and ideas is a huge reason why the country is what it is today. And yes, private companies have the right to do what they want on their platforms, but the principle works.
3. **I don't trust any group to decide what is and isn't acceptable** - Everyone has a different line for "hate speech" or "fake news" and I don't want either governments nor a few tech firms in San Francisco deciding what is and isn't acceptable. 
4. **If you give an inch, they'll take a mile** - Once "standards" are set, it won't end there. What's acceptable will change over time and it's a way of controlling people.

  2. I have the right to say what I want - Especially being from the US, freedom of speech and ideas is a huge reason why the country is what it is today. And yes, private companies have the right to do what they want on their platforms, but the principle works.
  3. I don't trust any group to decide what is and isn't acceptable - Everyone has a different line for "hate speech" or "fake news" and I don't want either governments nor a few tech firms in San Francisco deciding what is and isn't acceptable.
  4. If you give an inch, they'll take a mile - Once "standards" are set, it won't end there. What's acceptable will change over time and it's a way of controlling people.

A lot of you obviously give a shit about free speech, since you're here and not Reddit.

post.body_html:
A lot of you obviously give a shit about free speech, since you're here and not Reddit.

But why?

Why is it so important to you to be able to say any stupid thing that comes into your head, no matter how rude or awful or LITERALLY VIOLENT?

What does freedom of speech mean to you?
post.title: Why do you believe free speech is important?

body:
>But why?

Freedom of speech allows us to engage with one another, hopefully earnestly, but even if not, we still have the right to say what we will without government censorship.  And that's the key thing there, the government cannot tell us what to say.  Companies have the ability to censor speech, individuals have the right to censor speech inside their own private homes.

>Why is it so important to you to be able to say any stupid thing that comes into your head, no matter how rude or awful or LITERALLY VIOLENT?

To be able to have that freedom an exercise it.  That's it.  I have the ability to say whatever comes to my head, whether rude, awful, or "violent."  But I do not.

>What does freedom of speech mean to you?

The ability to say whatever I want, especially about the government, without the action of being censored for it, by the government.  There are caveats to that, one cannot yell "Fire!" in a theater without there being a fire as it endangers the public safety and our well-being.  That freedom of speech is limited.

Having conversations is wonderful, especially with those who you disagree with, so long as the conversations are level-headed, honest, and a conclusion can be come to whether or not the two, or more, people disagree.  There is quite a difference between having a conversation and being talked at.
body_html:
But why?

Freedom of speech allows us to engage with one another, hopefully earnestly, but even if not, we still have the right to say what we will without government censorship. And that's the key thing there, the government cannot tell us what to say. Companies have the ability to censor speech, individuals have the right to censor speech inside their own private homes.

Why is it so important to you to be able to say any stupid thing that comes into your head, no matter how rude or awful or LITERALLY VIOLENT?

To be able to have that freedom an exercise it. That's it. I have the ability to say whatever comes to my head, whether rude, awful, or "violent." But I do not.

What does freedom of speech mean to you?

The ability to say whatever I want, especially about the government, without the action of being censored for it, by the government. There are caveats to that, one cannot yell "Fire!" in a theater without there being a fire as it endangers the public safety and our well-being. That freedom of speech is limited.

Having conversations is wonderful, especially with those who you disagree with, so long as the conversations are level-headed, honest, and a conclusion can be come to whether or not the two, or more, people disagree. There is quite a difference between having a conversation and being talked at.
